more than maybe three weeks beforehand preferably two but the drilling method has been the best the main issue with the drilling that I see my part of the area with the biomass that we have over there residue I've seen too many fields where the guys started bright and early in the morning a shitty stand nice nice stance starting about 1/2 o'clock in the afternoon you can tell right where is that lady evening it goes back to crap again just because they were not cutting through this thick matter residue I know these seeds are small but you need to get them in the seed to soil contact I'm not going to cover that but we do have some termination guidelines and it does affect this area area if you do summer fallow and you try to put a cover crop on summer fallow it does affect this area because as of right now RMA insurance says that that cover crop needs to be terminated in 90 days before planting that next crop okay so the guys with fellow with winter wheat definitely going to impact you the guys with fallow going to spring wheat and you may be able to get by with that but check with NRCS we have this part of a it's attached to a practice standard if you're not familiar with it but one of your offices know and they can get that for you but in summary the benefits of cover crops accrue over several years you will see improvements in crop yield pest management and soil tilth if you commit to cover crop use whenever and wherever possible in your rotation and that's all I have so with that do I have any questions so let's write that for lunch I know it's just as hard for me as if for you guys great I got off easy
